item.title: Aonidiella orientalis
item.author: Uri Gerson
item.description:
Aonidiella orientalis (Newstead)

Taxonomic placing: Insecta, Hemimetabola, Hemiptera, Coccoidea, Diaspididae.

Common name: Oriental red scale.

Geographical distribution: South-East Asia, Australia, parts of Africa, Central America, Middle East. In Israel since 1980, now found in most mango-growing regions. Commonwealth Institute of Entomology Map #386, 1978.

Economic importance: A pest of many crops, including avocado, citrus, coconut, papaya and tea. In Israel A. orientalis is a minor pest of mango, settling on the leaves and twigs. The feeding sites on the fruit remain green even after color break, reducing their market value.

Host plants: Very polyphagous.

Morphology: The dorsal macroducts are one-barred, slender, usually three on each side of the pygidium. The pre-pygidial abdominal segments carry clusters of microducts. The female is rounded, initially yellow, later turning brown-red. After mating the fused prosoma and thorax become sclerotized, except for a central area extending from the pygidium to the mouth parts. The pygidium bears three lobes, the two median lobes externally and internally notched, the third only externally; the fourth lobe occurs as a mere point. The anus is located about two-thirds of the distance between the vulva and the median lobes. Three small paraphyses arise near the second and third lobes on either side of the pygidium. The ventral vulva lies between two clusters of about 10 perivulvar pores on either side, with 1-2 additional pores in front.

The shield is thick, flat, gray-white to brownish, round, the darker juvenile exuviae almost at center. The winged males are pale-orange, their dark shields oval, the paler exuvium of the 1st instar placed near one end.

Life cycle: The pest settles on mango leaves, twigs and fruit. Its populations peak in the winter, are low in the spring and increasing during late summer. The scale is more abundant on tree sides not exposed to the prevailing winds.

Management: The oriental red scale may be controlled by a mixture of two pesticides, an organophosphate and a carbamate.

Biological control: The oriental red scale is attacked by several hymenopterous endoparasitoids, including Comperiella bifasciata Howard and Habrolepis aspidioti Compere and Annecke, the aphelinid ectoparasitoids Aphytis melinus DeBach and Aphytis lingnanensis Compere, and the endoparasitoid Encarsia sp. It is not clear whether they contribute to the control of the pest.

References:

Badawi, A. and Alahmed, A.M. 1990. The population dynamics of the oriental scale insect, Aonidiella orientalis (Newstead) and factors affecting its seasonal abundance. Arab Gulf journal of Scientific Research 8: 81-89.

Wysoki, M., Ben-Dov, Y., Swirski, E. and Izhar, Y. 1993. The arthropod pests of mango in Israel. Acta Horticulturae 341:452-466.

Wysoki, M., Israeli, Y. and Rosen, D. 1995. The oriental red scale, Aonidiella orientalis (Newstead) (Diaspididae): biology, phenology, geographic distribution and natural enemies in Israel. Israel Journal of Entomology 29: 267.

item.title: Aphytis holoxanthus
item.author: Uri Gerson
item.description:
Aphytis holoxanthus DeBach

Taxonomic placing: , Holometabola, Hymenoptera, Chalcidoidea, Aphelinidae.

Geographical distribution: Of South-Eastern Asia origin, this species was successfully introduced into Israel in 1956/57 and later into Australia, Florida, South Africa and South America.

Host: The Florida red scale, Chrysomphalus aonidum (L.) (Diaspididae).

Economic importance: An efficient natural enemy of the Florida red scale.

Morphology: The female is yellow, its size being from 0.7 to 0.9 mm.

Life cycle: Like other members of its genus, Aphytis holoxanthus is an ectoparasitoid of armored scale insects. The eggs are deposited through the shield on the host’s body; due to the fact that when molting the shields of these scales adhere to their bodies, the parasitoid can deposit only between molts. Its emerging larvae feed on the host and kill it; prior to pupation the larvae excrete their meconia. The pupa is free, and its eyes change from colorless to red to green, providing an indication of age. The adult emerges through an exit hole in the shield or by crawling out from underneath. It attacks 2nd-stage female scales, male pupae but mostly adult females, on which two or three juveniles may develop. It is an arrhenotokous species, requiring a fortnight to complete a generation at 28Â°C, each female producing about 35 offspring.

Aphytis holoxanthus has not become established in the inner, arid valleys of Israel. When co-occurring with another natural enemy of the Florida red scale, the endoparasitoid Pteroptrix smithi (Compere), the latter appears to be dominant. This may reflect the latter’s ability to parasitize all scale stages (whereas A. holoxanthus can attack the host only between its molts), to the reduced activity of A. holoxanthus on citrus fruit, and to its greater susceptibility to organophosphate pesticides. On the other hand, the parasite has not been affected by the acaricide dicofol or by juvenile hormone analoge IGR.

References

Peleg, B.A. 1988. Effect of a new phenoxy juvenile hormone analog on California red scale (Homoptera, Diaspididae), Florida wax scale (Homoptera, Coccidae) and the ectoparasitic Aphytis holoxanthus DeBach (Hymenoptera, Aphelinidae). Journal of Economic Entomology 81: 88-92.

item.title: Aphis spiraecola
item.author: Uri Gerson
item.description:
Aphis spiraecola (= citricola) Patch

Taxonomic placing: Insecta, Hemimetabola, Hemiptera, Sternorrhyncha, Aphidoidea, Aphididae.

Common name: Spirea aphid.

Geographical distribution: Almost cosmopolitan; in the Middle East since the late 1960âs. Commonwealth Institute of Entomology Map #256, 1969.

Host plants: Polyphagous.

Economic importance: The feeding of the spirea aphid on young citrus foliage in the spring causes severe, characteristic curling and deformation of young leaves and twigs. Blossoms and young fruit (especially of soft-skinned varieties) drop prematurely, and the trees may be stunted. The consequences of a secondary, autumnal peak in pest outbreak are usually less severe. In addition, infested trees are contaminated by the the pest’s abundant honeydew and subsequently-developing sooty mold. The aphid is a vector of the citrus tristeza virus and other plant viruses. Young avocado trees also suffer from the pest, as do peach and apple trees, and many ornamentals. On apples Aphis spiraecola has displaced Aphis pomi De Geer as the dominant aphid on its leaves. During recent years the injury caused by spirea aphid to citrus seems to have declined in the Middle East

Morphology: The body of apterous females is yellow-green, sometimes with a pink hue; the head, siphunculi and cauda are brown-black and the length of the body is 1.4-2.1 mm. The head and thorax of alate females are brown-black, the abdomen is green and the siphunculi and cauda are dark; body length is 1.4-2.0 mm.

Life cycle: In the Middle East the spirea aphid reproduces by viviparous parthenogenesis throughout the year, each female giving birth to about 60 progeny when feeding on citrus foliage. At 25ÂºC the pest completes a generation within 7-10 days. The threshold of development is around 2.5ÂºC, which means that the pest develops during winter and could explain its rapid, almost sudden infestation of citrus groves in early spring. The pestâs departure is also rapid and sudden, possibly due to khamsin events in early summer. During such events the aphids move from the newly-growing, external parts of the trees to its central area, often dropping to the ground and dying there. Such behavior is exacerbated on parched trees, uncommon on well-irrigated trees.

Management

Chemical control: Due to the fact that young trees are especially vulnerable to this pest, pest damage can be reduced by spraying only them; such control activities should not be undertaken during khamsins. Carbamates, some organophosphates and acetamiprid control the spirea aphid.

Biological control: The spirea aphid is attacked by predatory Cecidomyiidae, Chrysopidae, Coccinellidae and Syrphidae. However, due to the pestâs short life cycle and sudden arrival and departure from citrus, these predators have little effect on the aphidâs populations. Some endoparasitoid hymenopterous Aphidiidae attack A. spirea, but seldom complete their development therein; the causative mechanism is unknown. Several entomopathogenic fungi also infect the aphid, but none of these natural enemies appear to reduce the pestâs damage.

References

Mescheloff, E. and Rosen, D. 1993. Biosystematic studies on the Aphidiidae of Israel (Hymenoptera: Ichneumonoidea). 4. The genera Trioxys and Binodoxys. Israel Journal of Entomology 27: 31-47.

item.title: Aphis fabae
item.author: Uri Gerson
item.description:
Aphis fabae Scopoli

Taxonomic placing: Insecta, Hemiptera, Sternorrhyncha, Aphidoidea, Aphididae

Common name: Bean aphid

Geographical distribution: Worldwide, except in Australia. Commonwealth Institute of Entomology map # 174, 1963.

Host plants: Polyphagous, known to infest members of over 20 plant families.

Economic importance: The feeding of the bean aphid causes leaf and flower deformations that result in yield losses of beet, beans and tomato, and it also transmits several plant viruses. The pest’s honeydew is collected by ants, which appear to protect the pest from its natural enemies. In addition, the pest may also disseminate the spores of fungal plant pathogens.

Morphology: The body of the apterous female is brown to black and the cauda and siphunculi are black. Alate females are mostly black, with a greenish areas on the abdomen. The length of the female body is 1.7-2.8 mm.

Life cycle: In most of the Middle East A. fabae reproduces by parthenogenesis throughout the year; in cooler regions sexual forms occur in the autumn and the females lay overwintering eggs. When host plants become overcrowded during infestation, alatae occur and fly in search of other hosts; The annual solanaceous weed Solanum villosum Miller (woolly nightshade) is a major reservoir host for the pest. Ants, and especially Tapinoma spp., are often associated with the bean aphid.

Management

Chemical control: The pest is susceptible to organophosphates and to acetamiprid, whereas its reproduction seems to be enhanced by pyrethroids.

Biological control: the bean aphid is attacked by predatory Chrysopidae, Coccinellidae and Syrphidae, as well as by hymenopterous Aphidiidae, especially Lysiphlebus fabarum (Marchall). Several entomopathogenic fungi also infect the pest.

References

Hutt, H.J., Van Emden, H.F. and Baker, T. 1994. Stimulation of plant growth and aphid population by a formulation ingredient of cymbush (cypermethrin). Bulletin of Entomological Research 84: 509-513.

Kluth, S., Kruess, A. and Tscharntke, T. 2002. Insects as vectors of plant pathogens: mutualistic and antagonistic interactions. Oecologia 133: 193-199.

item.title: Tomato
item.author: Uri Gerson
item.description:
Tomato

Taxonomic placing: Taxonomic placing: Solanaceae.

Common name: Tomato.

Tomato is the common name given to the plant Lycopersicon esculentum (sometimes named Solanum lycopersicon) and to its edible fruit. This fruit is one of the most widely produced and consumed vegetables in the world, for fresh as well as for processed consumption (e.g. sauce, ketchup).

Tomato plants do best on well-drained soils that are slightly acidic. Although tomato is a perennial plant, it is usually cultivated as an annual. Its varieties are mostly classified as determinate or indeterminate. The former bear their entire crop at one time and grow to a specific height, whereas the indeterminate varieties develop into vines and continue growing and producing fruit. In addition some tomatoes, the indeterminate, grow only to a specific height but produce a second crop. In the field tomato is usually grown as recumbent plant, but in greenhouses it is trellised and may grow to a height of two meters or more. The stem produces a number of compound leaves, and they as well as the stem are covered with trichomes. Many trichomes have glandular heads, which contain toxic excretions and serve to repel pests.

The tomato fruit is a fleshy berry containing a soft inner tissue (the columella) surrounded by seeds, a soft pericarp and a thin skin which turns from green to red as the fruit matures. The fruit of the various varieties (of which there are several thousand) comes in many shapes, from large (up to 7 cm in diameter) and rounded, to small, cluster-like, 1.5-2.5 cm in diameter), as well as oval-shaped.

In Israel the commonly grown varieties are #1420 and #1912, and many others are in development. Transgenic tomato varieties were constructed but failed, mostly due to environmental concerns and to the availability of unmodified varieties that provide the same benefits.

World production of tomatoes came to about 110 million tons in 2003, of which China (ca 24% of total), USA (11%) and Turkey (8%, with 9,700,000 tons picked and 1,630,000 tons processed in 2005) were the main producers. About 405,000 tons were harvested in Israel in 2005, of which 230,000 tons were processed. In Jordan ca 50,000 tons were processed in the same year and in Syria 420,000 tons were picked, of which about 135,000 tons were processed.

Major tomato pests in the Middle East

Aculops lycopersici

Liriomyza trifolii

item.title: Aphytis chilensis
item.author: Uri Gerson
item.description:
Aphytis chilensis Howard

Taxonomic placing: Insecta, Holometabola, Hymenoptera, Chalcidoidea, Aphelinidae.

Geographical distribution: Cosmopolitan.

Hosts: Several armored scale insects (Diaspididae).

Economic importance: An important parasitoid of the oleander scale, Aspidiotus nerii Bouche.

Morphology: The female is yellow, its size being from 0.5 to 1.1 mm; smaller specimens are paler, bear less setae and were even described as a separate species (Aphytis riadi).

Life cycle: Like other members of its genus, Aphytis chilensis is an ectoparasitoid of armored scale insects. The 2nd-stage nymphs, young females and scale prepupae are attacked, but the ovipositing females are the preferred stage for parasitization. The eggs are deposited through the shield onto the host’s body.

(Figure 1)

Due to the fact that at molting the shields of these insects adhere to their bodies, the parasitoid can deposit only between molts. Its emerging larvae feed on the scales and prior to pupation they excrete their fecal matter (meconia). The pupa is free, and its eyes change from colorless to red to green, providing an indication of its age. The adult often emerges through an exit hole in the shield, or by crawling out from underneath. Although reared (in the field and in the laboratory) from several hosts, it seems to prefer the oleander scale. Aphytis chilensis is thelytokous (but males have been described), requiring ca 18 days to complete a generation at 28Â°C and each female produces about 25 offspring. In the field the parasitoid has two population peaks, in spring and in autumn. It attacks mainly young host females and is a voracious host feeder, killing more scales by this practice than by parasitization.

Water extract of the shield of the oleander scale elicited a positive response from A. chilensis, suggesting that its host-searching is based on chemical cues.

item.title: Aphis nerii
item.author: Uri Gerson
item.description:
Aphis nerii (Boyer de Fonscolombe)

Taxonomic placing: Insecta, Hemiptera, Sternorrhyncha, Aphidoidea, Aphididae.

Common name: oleander aphid, milkweed aphid.

Geographical distribution: Cosmopolitan in tropical to warm temperate regions. The oleander aphid is thought to have originated in the Mediterranean region, where its major host plant, oleander (Nerium oleander) in endemic.

Host plants: Aphis nerii develops primarily on plants of the family Apocyanaceae, but may occasionally infest Compositae, Convolvulaceae, and Euphorbiaceae. This pest is rarely found on citrus.

Economic importance: The pest’s occasional infestation of minor host plants may have some slight significance in the transmission of several important non-persistent virus diseases. Other than that, damage to ornamentals is primarily aesthetic. Like other aphids, A. nerii is a phloem-feeder, excreting honeydew that subsequently serves as a substrate for sooty mold.

Morphology: The body is bright yellow with black appendages. The alate female head and protnotum are dark whereas the remainder of the body is yellow, with dark wing veins. The apterate female is yellow with black siphunculi, antennae, legs, and cauda. Nymphs are similar to the apterates, except that they are smaller. Sizes range from 1.5 to 2.6 mm in length.

Life Cycle: No sexual forms have been observed in the field, all adult morphs being parthenogenic and viviparous apterous or alate females. There are five nymphal instars. Under optimal conditions of population density and fresh plant material, apterate generations proliferate. Summer populations are low due to the high temperatures, but during mild winters A. nerii may be abundant. Alate forms occur under conditions of overcrowding and as plant quality declines, and the winged adults migrate to find new host plants.

Management

Chemical control: Such control is seldom called for, but if necessary, insecticidal soaps or oils can be used.

Biological control: Many potential predators are deterred a priori by the presence of host-plant derived cardenolides, which are sequestered by the aphids and protect them. Aphis nerii is relatively insensitive to these toxins, and its aposematic bright yellow body color and associated black appendages serve as visual cues, declaring their unsuitability as prey. Cardenolides are also secreted by the siphunculi. As is common in complex tritrophic relations, some parasitoid and generalist insect predators are not deterred by these noxious semiochemicals. When parasitized, the parasitoids (usually of the hymenopterous family Aphidiidae) “mummify” their hosts, i.e., the normally soft aphid cuticle hardens and the developmental stages of the parasitoid are protected. This however does not reduce aesthetic damage to the crop. .

References

Moran, N. A. 1992. The evolution of aphid life cycles. Annual Review of Entomology 37, 321-348.

Martel JW and Malcolm SB. 2004. Density-dependent reduction and induction of milkweed cardenolides by a sucking insect herbivore. Journal of Chemical Ecology 30, 545-561.

item.title: Aphis punicae
item.author: Uri Gerson
item.description:
Aphis punicae Passerini

Taxonomic placing: Insecta, Hemimetabola, Hemiptera, Sternorrhyncha, Aphidoidea, Aphididae.

Common name: Pomegranate aphid.

Geographical distribution: Around the Mediterranean to Switzerland, Southern Russia to India.

Host plants: Pomegranate, various ornamentals (Duranta, Plumbago).

Economic importance: The feeding of A. punicae causes leaf drop, reductions in pomegranate fruit quality and stunts tree growth. The pestâs honeydew and ensuing sooty mold enhance these injuries.

Morphology: The body of the apterous female is light green, including the cauda and siphunculi, length of the female body is 1.0-2.0 mm. The head and thorax of alate females are dark, as are the siphunculi, whereas the abdomen and cauda are greenish and body length is 1.4-1.9 mm.

Life cycle: On the evergreen Duranta repens (golden dewdrop) the aphid reproduces by viviparous parthenogenesis throughout the year (autoecious cycle). On the deciduous pomegranate, however, sexual forms occur in winter, mate and the females (the âamphigonesâ) deposit their eggs in the leaf axils. The aphids that emerge in the following spring reproduce by viviparous parthenogenesis till autumn. The pest has spring and autumn population peaks.

The optimal conditions for the aphid, when reared on pomegranate, are between 22.5-25ÂºC, at which temperatures each female produces aboud 30 progeny. The threshold for development was calculated to be at 11.8ÂºC.

Management

Chemical control: This minor pest is susceptible to organophosphates that can be applied if needed.

Biological control: The pomegranate aphid is attacked by several hymenopterous endoparasitoids of the families Aphidiidae (of which the most promising is Lysiphlebus fabarum (Marshall)) and Aphelinidae.

item.title: Aphanostigma piri
item.author: Uri Gerson
item.description:
Aphanostigma piri (Cholodkovsky)

Taxonomic placing: Insecta, Hemimetabola, Hemiptera, Sternorrhyncha, Aphidoidea, Phylloxeridae .

Common name: Pear phylloxera.

Geographical distribution: Mediterranean region, Crimea, East Asia.

Host plants: Pyrus communis (pear), Pyrus syriaca (Syrian pear).

Economic importance: The pear phylloxera is a major pest of pears. Its sucking on the bark results in intensive cracking that can cause the death of branches. Infested buds are destroyed and brown, rotted areas develop around the calyx of affected fruit, which may then drop or be culled during packing. The cultivar âSpadonaâ is most susceptible.

Morphology: The body of apterous females is green to yellow, about 0.7-0.9 mm long. No alate forms known from the Middle East.

Life cycle: Groups of the pear phylloxera live throughout the year in the crevices of the bark, infesting buds and even the fruit calyx. It reproduces by viviparous parthenogenesis around the year, the populations peaking in spring and autumn. Each female can produce 70-150 progeny during its lifetime, which may last 3-4 weeks in summer, 10 weeks in winter. A generation is completed in about two weeks at 30ÂºC and the threshold of development is around 3.0ÂºC

Management

Monitoring: Observations of the cracked bark of mature pear trees should commence in May, whereas fruit monitoring is by marking 20 pears per tree and observing their condition till picking.

Plant resistance: Some pear cultivars, such as Gentil and Coscia, are little infested by the pest.

Chemical control: Pear phylloxera can be controlled with systemic organophosphates, although the pest may be developing resistance to this group of pesticides in Israel.

item.title: Aphis pomi
item.author: Uri Gerson
item.description:
Aphis pomi DeGeer

Taxonomic placing: Insecta, Hemiptera, Sternorrhyncha, Aphidoidea, entry/Aphididae.

Common name: Apple aphid.

Geographical distribution: Wherever apples are grown. Commonwealth Institute of Entomology map #87, 1969 (revised).

Host plants: Apple, pear quince and other members of the family Rosaceae.

Economic importance: The feeding of A. pomi causes downwards curling of young apple leaves, flower wilting and even plant stunting. Pale-green tubercles may arise on the young fruit. The pest transmits a plant virus. Its meager honeydew output is usually collected by ants, with little attendant sooty mold. The economic importance of the apple aphid has declined in recent years due to being displaced by the spirea aphid, _ Aphis spiraecola_ Patch.

Morphology: The body of the apterous female is light to dark green, the antennae are yellow and the cauda and siphunculi are dark green to black. Alate females are mostly black, with a greenish abdomen; otherwise they are similar to the apterae. The length of the female body is 1.5-2.2 mm.

Life cycle: The aphids usually live on the same host throughout the year (autoecious), overwintering as eggs placed on apple branches. In the spring the emerging aphids reproduce by parthenogenesis till autumn, when males and sexual females appear and mate. The threshold of development is around 6ÂºC, at 16-20ÂºC a generation requires about 12 days, and each female has a average of 70 progeny. Summer irrigation, which promotes apple growth, also encourages increases in the aphids’ populations. Prior infestations by the pear lace bug, the tingid Stephanitis pyri (Fabricius), hinder the settlement of A. pomi.

Management

Monitoring: Concentrations of pest eggs should be noted in autumn and observed for aphid emergence in early spring, especially on adventitious apple branches, which grow early and serve as feeding sites for A. pomi.

Chemical control: The pest is susceptible to organophosphates and can also be controlled by white oils and by insecticidal soaps. Best results in fruit-bearing orchards can be obtained when the trees are sprayed prior to blooming; seedlings should be treated when 10-20 are seen per terminal branch.

Biological control: Planting or leaving weed strips between apple rows encourages the populations of the generalist natural enemies of the apple aphid, such as predatory Chrysopidae, Cecidomyiidae, Coccinellidae, Hemiptera and Syrphidae, as well as spiders.

item.title: Aphytis coheni
item.author: Uri Gerson
item.description:
Aphytis coheni DeBach

Taxonomic placing: Insecta, Hymenoptera, Chalcidoidea, Aphelinidae.

Common name: None.

Geographical distribution: Probably a native of south-east Asia that had fortuitously arrived in Israel and Lebanon.

Hosts: California red scale, Aonidiella aurantii (Maskell), rarely other armored scale insects (Diaspididae).

Economic importance: An important natural enemy of the California red scale, especially in the inner, warmer and drier parts of Israel.

Morphology: The female is yellow, about 0.8 to 1.1 mm in length.

Life cycle: Like other members of its genus, Aphytis coheni is an ectoparasitoid of armored scale insects. The 2nd-stage nymphs, young females and scale prepupae are attacked, but the young ovipositing females are the preferred stage for parasitization. The eggs are deposited through the shield on the host’s body; due to the fact that when molting the shields of these scales adhere to their bodies, the parasitoid can deposit only between molts. Its emerging larvae feed on the scales and prior to pupation they excrete their fecal matter in the shape of black pellets (meconia). The pupa is free, its eyes changing from colorless to red to green, providing an indication of its age. The adult often emerges through an exit hole in the shield, or by crawling out from underneath. The California red scale is its major host, although the ectoparasitoid was also obtained from a few other armored scale hosts. Aphytis coheni is arrhenotokous, requiring 3-4 weeks at 20Â°C to complete a generation, 12 days at 28Â°C. Each female, whether mated or not, produces about 25 offspring; the parasitoid may place an average of 5 eggs in such hosts. At 24Â°C males live about three weeks, females slightly longer. Aphytis coheni is a voracious host feeder that kills twice as many scales by this practice than by parasitization.

In the field the populations of A. coheni have a mild spring peak. Its juveniles, which are protected during their development by the host’s shield, seem to be tolerant to high temperatures, but the adults, and especially the males, are very susceptible. The parasitoid’s presence in the inner, hotter and drier regions of Israel is probably due to lack of competition there from other parasitoids of the California red scale (which are more susceptible to arid conditions), not due to any intrinsic superior biological attributes.

Water extracts of the shield of the California red scale elicited positive responses from A. coheni, indicating that its host searching is based on chemical cues.

References

Avidov, Z., M. Balshin and U. Gerson. 1970. Studies on Aphytis coheni, a parasite of the California red scale, Aonidiella aurantii, in Israel. Entomophaga 15: 191-207.

Luck, R.F. and Uygun, N. 1986. Host recognition and selection by Aphytis species: response to California red, oleander and cactus scale cover extracts. Entomologia Experimentalis et Applicata 40 : 129-136.

item.author: Uri Gerson
item.description:
Aphytis chrysomphali (Mercet)

Taxonomic placing: Insecta, Holometabola, Hymenoptera, Chalcidoidea, Aphelinidae.

Common name: None.

Geographical distribution: Probably a native of the Mediterranean basin; its distribution is now almost cosmopolitan.

Hosts: Several armored scale insects (Diaspididae), especially California red scale, Aonidiella aurantii (Maskell).

Economic importance: A member of a guild of parasitoids that attack the California red scale. In Israel and Cyprus A. chrysomphali occurs only along the coastal plain.

Morphology: The female is yellow, its size is from 0.6 to 1.0 mm.

Life cycle: Like other members of its genus, A. chrysomphali is an ectoparasitoid of armored scale insects. The 2nd-stage nymphs, young females and scale prepupae are attacked, but the ovipositing females are the preferred stage for parasitization. The eggs are deposited through the shield on the host’s body; due to the fact that when molting the shields of these scales adhere to their bodies, the ectoparasitoid can deposit only between molts. Its emerging larvae feed on the scales and prior to pupation they excrete their fecal matter in the shape of black pellets (”meconia”). The pupa is free, its eyes changing from colorless to red to green, providing an indication of age. The adult often emerges through an exit hole in the host’s shield, or by crawling out from underneath. Although obtained from several armored scale hosts, it is best known as a parasitoid of the California red scale. Aphytis chrysomphali is a uniparental thelytokous species (with rare males) and a voracious host feeder, killing more scales by this practice than by parasitization. It completes a cycle in a fortnight at 25Â°C, at which temperature each female produces about 25 offspring. It appears to be tolerant to low temperatures but susceptible to heat and aridity, attributes that could explain its prevalence along the coastal plain.

item.title: Aphidoidea
item.author: Uri Gerson
item.description:
Aphidoidea

Taxonomic placing: Insecta, Hemimetabola, Hemiptera, Sternorrhyncha.

Common name: Aphids, plant lice.

Geographical distribution: World-wide, with more species in the Northern temperate regions. This superfamily consists of close to 5,000 described species that are usually (although not universally) assigned to three families: Adelgidae (=Chermesidae), Phylloxeridae and Aphididae. The former two are sometimes separated from the latter family because they reproduce only by depositing eggs, whereas the Aphididae lay eggs as well as being viviparous.

Morphology: Relatively small, soft-skinned insects with a clear separation into head, thorax, or abdomen, and functional sucking mouth parts in both sexes. The long rostrum consists of 4-5 segments and the antennae have 3-6 segments. The translucent wings, when present, bear reduced venation. The fifth or sixth abdominal segments carry a pair of dorsal funnel-like appendages, the siphunculi (or cornicles) and the hind segment has a tail-like appendage, termed cauda. Adults may be alate (winged) or apterous (lacking wings), and a few species are polymorphic in their larval stages.

Life Histories: All Aphidoidea are plant feeders and usually undergo four nymphal stages. They show a diversity of developmental histories, species alternating between parthenogenetic and sexual generations; the occurrence of the latter is often induced by changes in daylight length and temperature. Many species shift when winged between unrelated host plants. This may be induced by crowding, degradation of food resources, temperature and photoperiod. Many species are attended and protected by ants, which exploit the aphid’s honeydew and concurrently hinder the biological control of pest species.

Economic Importance: The aphids, which are phloem feeders, include many major plant pests. Damage may from depletion of nutrients from host plants, injection salivary toxins that induce deformation, including galls, secreting copious amounts of honey dew that serve as substrates to sooty mold fungi, and the transmission of many plant viruses. Aphids attack annuals as well as perennials and cause much damage to nut and fruit trees, forests, and greenhouse crops, including ornamentals.

Distribution and Ecology: Aphids occur in nearly all available botanical habitats, from the tundra to the tropics, and are found on all parts of host plants: leaves, branches, trunks, fruits, and roots.

item.title: Aphididae
item.author: Uri Gerson
item.description:
Aphididae

Taxonomic placing: Insecta, Hemimetabola, Hemiptera, Sternorrhyncha, Aphidoidea

Common name: Aphids, plant lice

Geographical distribution: World-wide, with close to 4,000 described species that are more abundant in the Holarctic region.

Morphology: Relatively small, soft-skinned insects with a clear separation into head, thorax, or abdomen, and functional sucking mouth parts in both sexes. The rostrum is made up of 4-5 segments and the antennae have 4-6 segments. The translucent wings, when present, bear reduced venation. The fifth or sixth abdominal segments carry a pair of dorsal siphunculi and the terminal segment bears an extension, the cauda. Adults may be alate (and then usually with darker bodies) or apterous.

Life Histories: All Aphididae are plant feeders and usually undergo four nymphal stages. They may lay eggs as well as being viviparous and show a diversity of developmental histories, species changing between parthenogenesis and sexual reproduction, and sometimes alternating between unrelated host plants. A major factor that affects the population fluctuations of many aphids in the Middle East is their susceptibility to khamsins. Due to this and other local climatic conditions, numerous species that infest perennials remain on their hosts throughout the year and reproduce only by parthenogenesis.

Economic Importance: The aphids, which are phloem feeders, include many major plant pests. Their damage is due to sucking out nutrients from host plants and injecting salivary toxins into them, inducing the formation of galls, secreting copious amounts of honey dew that serve as substrates for sooty mold fungi, and to transmitting harmful plant viruses. They attack annuals as well as perennials and cause much damage to greenhouse and house plants, nut and fruit trees and to forests.

Distribution and Ecology: Aphids occur in nearly all available botanical habitats from the tundra to the tropics and infest all parts of the host including the leaves, branches, trunks, fruits, and roots. Their natural enemies include many generalist predators belonging to the Coleoptera, Hemiptera and Neuroptera, as well as hymenopterous endoparasitoids, especially of the family Aphidiidae, which are specialized on aphids.

item.title: Schistocerca gregaria
item.author: Uri Gerson
item.description:
Schistocerca gregaria (Forskal)

Taxonomic placing: Insecta, Hemimetabola, Orthoptera, Acridoidea, Acrididae, Cyrtacanthacridinae.

Common name: Desert locust.

Geographical distribution: ranging from West Africa, across the Arabian peninsula and most of the Indian sub-continent. In the Mediterranean region: all of northern Africa, the Middle East north to parts of Turkey, Iran and the Central Asian Republics.

Host plants: highly polyphagous, feeding mainly on a large variety of rangeland shrubs and grasses that grow in primary breeding sites and on economic crops when encountered during pest outbreaks.

Economic importance: Damage caused by the desert locust is a consequence of its polyphagous nature, the density of the population, and its habits to aggregate and swarm. Each individual gregarious locust is able to consume roughly its own weight in foliage daily. This partly explains how dense swarms of adults, or marching bands of nymphs, can inflict considerable injury in a short time. Damage by gregarious swarming populations occurs in cycles, in most cases afflicting economies in fragile ecosystems, least able to sustain biomass reduction or complete crop loss. In the long term, the cumulative damage does not surpass that inflicted by indigenous grasshoppers.

Morphology: When reared in isolation and consequently solitariform, locusts exhibit convex pronotal crests, typical morphometric ratios of body measurements, and cryptic green to light-brown coloration usually harmonizing with the color of the immediate environment and affected by humidity. Cuticular accumulation of melanin is markedly reduced. In contrast gregariform locusts, crowded during rearing, have concave or straight pronota, and are yellow with contrasted melanized and reddish marking. When adult but immature, the background color of both sexes of the desert locust has a pink caste. The mature adult gregariform male is yellowish, progressing to bright yellow, that of females brownish. Solitariform adults retain their green to brown coloration and convex pronota.

Life cycle: Eggs of the desert locust develop and hatch in about two weeks. Gregariform nymphs pass through five instars before maturing to the adult stage, while solitariform nymphs pass through six instars. Solitariform individuals tend to disperse and exhibit low activity. Gregariform nymphs tend to aggregate, and they are more active than solitariform nymphs.

Ecology: Nymphal development requires about one month under optimal conditions, but may extend for 2-3 months under less favorable conditions. Newly-eclosed adults are reproductively immature. During their pre-reproductive period the adults accumulate reserves in preparation for migration and/or reproduction. Reproductive maturation occurs within about three weeks but may be delayed for many months, in synchrony with the environment. There is evidence that delayed maturation within primary breeding sites is synchronized with rainfall and flowering of desert shrubs.

During periods of recession, desert locusts breed in primary breeding sites, mainly restricted to semi-arid and arid deserts where precipitation is sporadic and below 200 mm annually. Rainfall in primary breeding sites initiates seed germination. This sequence of events subsequently leads to an increased population density. Within 2-3 generations of increasing density, transformation to the gregariform phase is induced. When these conditions cease, and a dry spell occurs, adults swarm gregariously, migrating actively in the direction of prevailing winds. In Africa, migration is associated with the Inter-Tropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ). When opposing winds meet within this zone, high air pressure develops and vertical flow of air occurs. During its ascent, air temperature decreases leading to an increase in relative humidity and finally to rainfall. The arrival of locust swarms to the convergence zone coincides with the occurrence of precipitation and vegetation, encouraging and supporting further population growth.

Females contribute to gregarization by depositing egg pods close to pods that are being laid concurrently or have been laid previously. This is due to their attraction to ovipositional sites, whether because of suitability of soil, moisture and other environmental conditions, or to attraction to an oviposition pheromone with which each female marks the exact spot wherein she has deposited eggs. Clutches of eggs are bound together with a proteinaceous foam, which is produced in the female genital accessory glands. Solitarious females produce and deposit more eggs (60-80) in each clutch than do gregarious females (40-60).

Swarming behavior and migration are not necessarily dependent on gregariform phase characteristics of coloration or morphometrics, but are usually positively correlated to population density: Gregarious behavior is induced as a consequence of interactions among individuals upon crowding, irrespective of whether they are initially solitariform or gregariform in coloration and morphometrics. Solitarious behavior is conversely expressed when locusts are isolated, even when initially gregariform. Solitarious larvae do not aggregate, whereas gregarious locusts are marked with bright color patterns, tend to aggregate in their nymphal stages and to march together in bands, while adults fly in dense and highly mobile swarms. Locust flight is directed by prevailing winds. These directions differ from night to day. Locusts ascend on thermal currents during the day to considerable heights, where they may encounter wind directions differing from those found at lower altitudes.

The area covered by gregarious locust swarms may range from 1 to 200 square kilometers, at a density which is commonly in the range of 100 individual per square meter, but under extreme conditions may be one to two orders of magnitude greater in density.

Another characteristic of sustained flight or migration, is that reproduction is normally delayed. This may be due to the allocation for flight of limited resources in the first case, or allocation of the same resource pool for egg development, in the second. This differential allocation of resources is termed the oocyte-flight syndrome.

Management

Control: Populations of the Desert Locust are monitored during recession and outbreak by various international agencies. These include the Desert Locust Control Organization (DLCO) of the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) of the United Nations. When gregarization commences, outbreak is prevented primarily by chemical control, preferably with less persistent chemicals, such as the pyrethroids fenitrothion and deltamethrin, the insect growth regulator (IGR) diflubenzuron, the carbamate bendiocarb and the GABA-blocker fipronil. Neem seed extracts, whether prepared locally or commercially, are effective as feeding deterrents of the desert locust.

The best chance to restrict locust outbreak is by careful monitoring and control of evolving gregarization. There are several reasons why this is not always logistically possible, or indeed efficient. Primarily, this is because breeding sites are sporadic and spread over a very wide area, often in remote location. Access to many of these sites is difficult, security questionable, and resources limited. Finally, the cycles of desert locust outbreaks and recessions are extended, and this leads to loss of attention during extended recession periods. There is a recurrent debate concerning the long-term economic justification of global locust control.

Biological Control: Various parasites and predators have been reported to attack the different stages of Desert Locust development. None are effective in suppressing populations once they have gregarized and swarmed. They may contribute to some degree to the collapse of locust populations, once the outbreak had peaked. Recent studies with preparations of the entomopathogenic fungus Metarhizium anisopliae are encouraging.
